Influence of Al, Cr, Ga, or Zr as promoters on the performance of Cu/ZnO catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol Cássia S. Santana Investigation Methodology Writing – original draft Visualization Data curation a Letícia F. Rasteiro Data curation Writing – review & editing b Francielle C.F. Marcos Methodology Writing – review & editing c Elisabete M. Assaf Resources Supervision Writing – review & editing b Janaina F. Gomes Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ José M. Assaf Conceptualization Supervision Writing – review & editing Funding acquisition a ⁎ a Department of Chemical Engineering, São Carlos Federal University, São Carlos, São Paulo 13565-905, Brazil Department of Chemical Engineering São Carlos Federal University São Carlos São Paulo 13565-905 Brazil aDepartment of Chemical Engineering, São Carlos Federal University, São Carlos, São Paulo 13565-905, Brazil b São Carlos Institute of Chemistry, University of São Paulo, São Carlos, São Paulo 13566-590, Brazil São Carlos Institute of Chemistry University of São Paulo São Carlos São Paulo 13566-590 Brazil bSão Carlos Institute of Chemistry, University of São Paulo, São Carlos, São Paulo 13566-590, Brazil c Escola Politécnica of University of São Paulo, University of São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo 05508-010, Brazil Escola Politécnica of University of São Paulo University of São Paulo São Paulo São Paulo 05508-010 Brazil cEscola Politécnica of University of São Paulo, University of São Paulo, São Paulo, São Paulo 05508-010, Brazil ⁎ Corresponding authors. Different promoters can be applied to increase the activity, selectivity, and stability of the Cu/ZnO for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Herein, we investigated the effect of the promoters' addition on the physicochemical properties of the Cu/ZnO-based catalysts and their performance in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. A series of Cu/ZnO catalysts, Cu/ZnO/X (X = Al2O3, Cr2O3, Ga2O3, ZrO2), were prepared by a co-precipitation method and characterized by XRF, XRD, SEM, TEM, TEM-EDS, H2-TPR, N2O passivation, and CO2-TPD. Under the explored conditions, the promoters enhanced the catalyst activity and selectivity to methanol in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The superior performance of the promoted materials was associated with the increase of specific surface area, metallic copper surface area, basicity, and the decrease of the size of copper oxide crystallites and particles. Among the investigated materials, Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 (CZG) catalyst showed the best performance in terms of activity (XCO2, 200°C = 5.2%) and methanol selectivity (SMeOH, 200°C = 50%). Graphical abstract Image, graphical abstract Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Cu/ZnO catalysts Promoters Data availability Data will be made available on request. 1 Introduction Rising atmospheric carbon dioxide (CO2), primarily from human fossil fuel combustion, contributes to global climate change. For this reason, strategies to reduce CO2 emissions and control the increase of its atmospheric levels are urgent. In this scenario, a promising strategy comprises the development of alternative routes to fabricate chemical products based on carbon in which CO2 may be used as raw material. In general, CO2 can be catalytically converted into some fuels, such as hydrocarbons, alcohols, and so on [1]. Particularly, methanol is an important product that can be obtained from the CO2 hydrogenation reaction [2]. Methanol is currently produced on Cu/Zn-based catalyst from syngas at approximately 5-10 MPa and 200-300°C. One of the difficulties associated with the production of methanol from CO2 and H2 is the low activity and stability at low pressures and temperatures of some catalysts [3–5]. To overcome the above-cited limitations of synthesizing methanol from CO2 hydrogenation reaction, a good strategy to improve the performance of Cu/Zn-based catalysts is the addition of promoters. It has been reported by the literature that the use of transition metal oxide as promoters, such as Fe2O3 [6,7], Nb2O5 [8], Ga2O3 [9,10], ZrO2 [11,12], CeO2 [13], In2O3 [14], Cr2O3 [7,15], Al2O3 [16,17], Y2O3 [18], can modulate the Cu/Zn-based catalysts properties, maximizing interface sites, increasing the copper dispersion, metallic area of Cu, and the basicity of the material. As a result, the adsorption of CO2 and the H2 activation capacity are facilitated, new surface oxygen vacancies are created, the activity and selectivity are improved enhancing the methanol synthesis. Recently, Cored et al. showed the effect of gallium on the properties of Cu/ZnO catalysts prepared by a coprecipitation method, using NaOH or NH4HCO3 as precipitating agents [9]. The Ga3+-doped ZnO wurtzite phase on Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 was observed for the material coprecipitated with NaOH (CZG-NaOH), while the formation of ZnGa2O4 was evidenced for the coprecipitation with NH4HCO3 (CZG-NH4HCO3). The promoting effect of gallium on CZG-NaOH led to (i) an increase in the number of basic sites, favoring the adsorption of CO2, (ii) an enhancement of reduced ZnOx species, and (iii) a stabilization of Cu species. The optimization of these properties contributed to a better performance of CZG-NaOH for synthesizing methanol from CO2 and H2 [9]. In another study, Chen et al. compared the performance of ZnO/ZrO2, Cu/ZrO2, Cu/ZnO, and Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts for the production of methanol from CO2 and H2 [12]. Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 exhibited the best catalytic performance among the investigated materials. It was pointed out that the ZrO2 has a crucial role in improving the adsorption of CO2 and the selectivity to CH3OH It was also explored the morphology of the ZnO in the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 material. The authors showed that the flower-like ZnO presented the best results in terms of methanol space-time yield because of a higher amount of oxygen vacancies in this material compared to the Cu/ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts with a plate or rod-like ZnO morphology [12]. In line with these works, we investigated the catalytic performance of Cu/Zn catalyst promoted by Al, Cr, Ga, or Zr towards the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. These elements have been previously investigated as promoters for the Cu/ZnO catalyst, but a systematic study to compare their performance under the same reaction conditions, and using the same methodology to synthesize them, is still lacking in the literature. In this work, the materials were synthesized by the co-precipitation method, keeping the molar ratio Cu:Zn:X = 50:45:5 (X = Al, Cr, Ga, Zr), characterized by different techniques and applied to the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. In conjunction with the characterization results, how these different promoters can affect the activity and the selectivity of Cu/Zn catalyst to methanol synthesis from the CO2 hydrogenation reaction was explored. 2 Experimental section 2.1 Catalyst preparation The unpromoted CuO/ZnO (CZ) and CuO/ZnO/X (X = Al2O3 – CZA, Cr2O3 – CZC, Ga2O3 – CZG, ZrO2 – CZZ) materials were prepared via the traditional coprecipitation method by using Cu(NO3)2.3H2O, Zn(NO3)2.6H2O, Al(NO3)3.9H2O, Cr(NO3)3.9H2O, Ga(NO3)3.xH2O, and Cl2.OZr.8H2O salts as precursors. Typically, 25 mL of deionized water containing appropriate amounts of precursor salts was slowly added dropwise into 400 mL of 0.1 mol.L−1 NaHCO3 at 60°C and vigorously stirred. When the pH deviated from 7, NaHCO3 (1 mol.L−1) was slowly added into the solution to keep the pH between 7 and 8. Finally, the solid formed was aged for 4 h, separated, washed by several centrifugation runs, dried at 80°C for 12 h, and calcined with a ramp of 2°C.min−1 at 450°C for 4 h. The molar composition of the catalyst was Cu:Zn = 50:50 and Cu:Zn:X = 50:45:5. The catalysts were designated as CZ, CZA, CZC, CZG, CZZ, where the third letter corresponds to the added promoter, Al, Cr, Ga, and Zr, respectively. 2.2 Catalysts characterization X-ray fluorescence (XRF) spectroscopy was employed to investigate the chemical compositions of the catalysts using an energy-dispersive X-ray spectrometer (Shimadzu EDX-720). The crystallography of the materials was studied by X-ray diffraction (XRD, Rigaku Multiflex diffractometer) with CuKα radiation (λ = 1.5406 Å; 40 kV; 20 mA), from 2θ = 20° to 80°, using a goniometer speed of 5°.min−1. XRD results were compared with patterns from Powder Diffraction File (PDF) database. In addition, crystallite sizes were calculated using the Scherrer equation [19]. The specific surface areas of the materials were determined by N2 physisorption at -196°C, applying the Brunauer, Emmett, and Teller method (SBET) [20]. The experiments were performed with a Micromeritics ASAP 2020 instrument. The samples were pretreated under vacuum for 2 h at 200°C. Morphological features were investigated by scanning electron microscopy (SEM, Philips, XL30 FEG) and transmission electron microscopy (TEM, FEI, Tecnai G2 F20) operated at 200 kV and equipped with an energy dispersive X-ray detector (EDS). For each sample, three regions were explored in the EDS analysis, and the results presented correspond to an average of these regions. Temperature-programmed analyses (H2-TPR and N2O passivation) were performed using a Micromeritics Pulse ChemSorb 2750. For the H2-TPR experiment, ∼50 mg of sample was pre-treated with Ar flowing at 30 mL min−1, from room temperature to 450°C at a heating rate of 10°C min−1. After that, the sample was cooled down under the same atmosphere to 40°C and, subsequently, heated up to 750°C, at 10°C min−1, under a 10% H2/Ar (v/v) mixture flowing at 30 mL min−1. The hydrogen consumption was monitored by a thermal conductivity detector (TCD). For the N2O passivation experiment, the same sample loading was pre-treated, as described for the H2-TPR experiment. The first reduction cycle started by reducing the Cu oxides under a flow of 30 mL.min−1 10% H2/Ar (v/v) at 300°C for 1 h. Subsequently, the sample was cooled down to 40°C under a flow of Ar (30 mL.min−1). Then, 30 mL.min−1 of N2O/He (10% v/v) was flowed for 30 min, followed by 30 min of Ar flow (30 mL.min−1) to remove the N2O physically adsorbed. Finally, the second reduction cycle was carried out, following the same conditions as the first one. The copper dispersion (DCu), and the metallic copper area (ACu) were calculated as described by the literature [21,22]. Temperature-programmed desorption of CO2 (CO2-TPD) was performed using a Micromeritics Autochem II 2920 Chemisorption Analyzer. A similar procedure used for the N2O passivation was also used for CO2-TPD with few differences. The first step was the pre-treatment of the sample (∼75 mg) at 450°C under He flow (30 mL.min−1). After that, the sample was cooled down and heated up to 300°C, at 10°C.min−1, under a flow of 30 mL.min−1 of H2/N2 (10% v/v) and kept at 300°C under a reducing atmosphere for 1 h. The sample was again cooled down to 50°C under a flow of He (30 mL.min−1) and, at this temperature, was exposed to a CO2 flow of 30 mL.min−1 for 30 min. After the CO2 chemisorption step, a purge with He was performed for 1 h. Finally, under a flow of 30 mL.min−1 of He, the temperature was raised to 300°C, at 10°C.min−1. The CO2 desorbed during this process was monitored by a TCD detector and estimated by integrating the peak under the curves from room temperature to 300°C. 2.3 Catalytic evaluation CO2 hydrogenation was performed in a commercial high-pressure Microactivity Effi reactor from PID Eng&Tech, applying H2/CO2 = 3/1 (total flow 20 mL.min−1) and using 0.2 g of catalyst diluted with 0.4 g of SiC. In a typical experiment, the catalyst was pre-treated in situ under H2 flow (30 mL.min−1) at 300°C, using 10°C min−1 of heating rate, for 1 h, under atmospheric pressure. Then, under the N2 atmosphere, the sample was cooled down to the reaction temperature (between 200°C and 280°C), followed by the pressure increase up to 3 MPa with the reactants flow (CO2 + H2). The exit gases were analyzed in-line using a GC Agilent 7890A equipped with two detectors (thermal conductivity detector – TCD, and flame ionization detector – FID) and three columns (HP-MOLESIEVE, HP-PONA, and HP-Plot/Q). The CO2 conversion (XCO2), selectivity to methanol (SMeOH) or CO (SCO), and the space-time yield of methanol (STYMeOH) were determined as follows [11,23]: X C O 2 = n ˙ ( CO 2 in ) − n ˙ ( CO 2 out ) n ˙ ( CO 2 in ) . 100 % S i = n ˙ ( i out ) n ˙ ( CO 2 in ) − n ˙ ( CO 2 out ) . 100 % ST Y MeOH = n ˙ ( CO 2 in ) . X C O 2 . S C H 3 OH m cat . M M C H 3 OH where X C O 2 is the CO2 conversion; n ˙ ( CO 2 in ) and n ˙ ( CO 2 out ) are the molar flows of CO2 at the reactor inlet and outlet, respectively; S i is the selectivity to product i ( i = CH3OH or CO); n ˙ ( i out ) is the outlet molar flow of the product i (i = CH3OH or CO); ST Y MeOH is the space-time yield of the methanol; m cat is the mass of the material used in the catalytic experiment; M M C H 3 OH is the molecular weight of methanol (32 g.mol−1). 3 Results and discussion 3.1 Catalyst characterization Fig. 1 shows the XRD patterns of the catalysts. As can be seen, the XRD profiles reveal the crystalline nature of the synthesized materials. The characteristic diffraction peaks between 10° and 80° correspond to the tenorite phase of CuO with monoclinic structure (PDF 48-1548) and ZnO with wurtzite hexagonal structure (PDF 36-1451). For the promoted materials, the absence of peaks associated with the promoters Al2O3 (Fig. 1b), Cr2O3 (Fig. 1c), Ga2O3 (Fig. 1d), or ZrO2 (Fig. 1e) indicates that these oxide species are in an amorphous phase in the materials or their crystalline phase is highly dispersed in the Cu-ZnO structure [8]. Using the Scherrer equation and the main diffraction peak of each phase (2θ = 38.7° - CuO and 2θ = 36.3° - ZnO), the average crystallite sizes of the CuO (dCuO) and the ZnO (dZnO) were estimated [19]. These data are presented in Table 1 , which also shows other properties of the materials. The average size of copper oxide crystallite (dCuO) and zinc oxide crystallite (dZnO) for the CZ was 15 nm and 24 nm, respectively. For the promoted materials, the values ranged from 6 to 11 nm. In particular, the addition of Al (CZA), Cr (CZC), Ga (CZG), and Zr (CZZ) as promoters to the CZ catalyst led to a reduction compared to the unpromoted material of 53%, 27%, 60%, and 40%, respectively, in the average crystallite size of CuO and 63%, 63%, 75%, and 54%, respectively, in the average crystallite size of ZnO. These results indicate that the promoters, regardless of their chemical nature, inhibit the growth of CuO and ZnO, favoring the formation of smaller crystallites. These data are in good agreement with previous studies [8,24]. The chemical composition was determined by XRF spectroscopy (Table 1). It was observed that the experimental values are close to the nominal values. The molar contents of Cu, Zn, and promoters were kept around 50%, 45%, and 5%, respectively. The specific surface area ranged between 9 and 41 m2.g−1 (Table 1). In the presence of the promoters, the specific surface area of the materials increased by up to 4.5 times compared to that of the unpromoted material (CZ). This significant increase may be associated with the formation of relatively smaller oxide particles [23]. These results are consistent with the XRD data (Table 1). For example, CZA and CZG, which presented the largest specific surface areas among the investigated materials, showed the smallest average sizes of CuO crystallite (Table 1). The morphology of the materials was evaluated by SEM and TEM analysis, as presented in Fig. 2 (a and b). As can be seen in Fig. 2a, the use of distinct promoters led to the formation of materials with different morphologies, with irregular aggregates. These data are consistent with varying specific surface areas observed in Table 1, although the XRD results revealed that these catalysts have similar crystalline structures (Fig. 1). As shown in Fig. 2b, the investigated materials present particles with an uneven size and geometry. This characteristic is common for materials synthesized by single-step co-precipitation methods, in which the formation of crystallites of metallic oxides is influenced by chemical interactions between different species. These interactions can prevent or even favor the preferential growth of specific crystallographic planes [25]. In terms of particle size, promoted materials (CZA, CZC, CZG, CZZ) presented smaller particles than the unpromoted one (CZ), corroborating the XRD and the specific surface area data. The surface distribution of the elements was investigated by EDX (Fig. 3 ). The element mapping images provide legible evidence for the homogeneous distribution of copper, zinc, and promoters in the materials. This feature is especially important to maximize interface areas among the elements and to optimize the performance of multicomponent catalysts. Temperature-programmed reduction with H2 (H2-TPR) measurements of the investigated catalysts are shown in Fig. 4 , and the obtained profiles were deconvoluted by fitting Gaussian functions. For all samples, the broad peak below 300°C is ascribed to the hydrogen consumption associated with the reduction of Cu2+ to Cu0 (CuO + H2 → Cu0 + H2O). It can be deconvoluted into two peaks, α and β, suggesting that there are different kinds of CuO species. The α peak can be assigned to more structurally dispersed CuO species interacting with ZnO, while the β peak relates to CuO weakly interacting with the Zn or with the promoters or bulk-like copper oxide species. For the promoted materials, α and β peaks occurred at lower temperatures than those observed for CZ. Therefore, the addition of the promoters favored the reducibility of CuO. The trends of the specific surface area (Table 1), particle size (Fig. 2b), and CuO reduction temperature of the investigated materials were similar, indicating a relationship among these properties. Smaller particle sizes and higher specific surface areas facilitated the CuO reduction at lower temperatures, agreeing with previous studies [11,26]. Above 400°C the reduction of ZnO to Zn° was observed (γ peak) in good agreement with the literature [11,27]. Furthermore, the reduction of the promoters within the experimental range evaluated (50°C – 750°C) was not observed. From the temperature range of the CuO reduction (Fig. 4), the reduction temperature of the materials in the pre-treatment preceding the CO2 hydrogenation reaction was defined as 300°C. The analysis by N2O passivation was performed to gain further insight into the copper dispersion (DCu) and metallic copper area (ACu) (Table 1). According to the data, the DCu and ACu ranged between 1.2 and 7.8%, 2.6 and 11.5 m2.gcat −1, respectively. A remarkable increase was observed when comparing the ACu of the CZ with those of the promoted materials (CZA, CZC, CZG, CZZ). These results strongly suggest that the addition of the promoters inhibited the aggregation of Cu and a similar behavior has been previously reported in the literature [28,29]. The number of basic sites of the materials was investigated by CO2-TPD (Table 1) and followed the order: CZ < CZC < CZA < CZG < CZZ. This result shows that the promoters favored the CO2 adsorption by creating new basic sites due to the increase of the surface areas, in addition to decrease the Cu particles sizes, in good agreement with the literature [3,30]. 3.2 Catalytic evaluation Effects of reaction temperature on the activity and selectivity of the materials applied to the CO2 hydrogenation reaction are shown in Fig. 5 . The CZ catalyst presented values of CO2 conversion between 2% and 10%. The promoted materials were more active in the investigated temperature range when compared to CZ, exhibiting CO2 conversions between 4% and 17%. The highest CO2 conversion was evidenced on the CZG catalyst. According to the N2O passivation analysis, CZA, CZC, CZG, and CZZ presented larger Cu dispersions and metallic areas than those of CZ. These parameters have been directly related to the activity of Cu-based catalysts applied to the CO2 hydrogenation reaction [31]. Higher dispersions and metallic areas of Cu increase the interfacial contact between copper and the oxide support, facilitating the adsorption and activation of CO2 and the spillover of H2 from Cu0 to the adsorbed CO2 [3,32]. From the TEM images (Fig. 2b), smaller particles were formed in the presence of the promoters compared to those of the unpromoted material (CZ). Smaller particles have a higher proportion of coordinately unsaturated sites and, therefore, they tend to be less stable and more reactive than larger particles, increasing the catalyst activity [25]. Under the reaction conditions applied in this work, it was observed the formation of CH3OH, CO, and only traces of CH4 (< 0.5%) (Fig.5). In general, the selectivity to methanol decreased with increasing temperature between 200°C and 280°C. An opposite behavior was observed for CO selectivity. The formation of CO is associated with the reverse water gas-shift reaction (rWGS), which competes with the methanol formation. The shift in Gibbs free energy (ΔG°) governs the spontaneity of a chemical reaction. According to the thermodynamic analysis of methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation reaction [5,33], the ΔG° for methanol synthesis reaction increases with temperature, which means that this reaction is favored at lower temperatures. On the other hand, the ΔG° for the rWGS reaction decreases with temperature implying that the rWGS is favored at higher temperatures. In the investigated temperature range, the promoted materials were more selective to methanol and less selective to CO than the unpromoted material (CZ). CZG presented the highest selectivity to methanol. For example, at 200°C, CZG and CZA catalysts showed methanol selectivity of 50% and 32%, respectively, compared to 22% for the CZ. On the other hand, at the same temperature, these materials showed CO selectivity of 50% (CZG) and 68% (CZA) compared to 78% for the unpromoted material (CZ). Therefore, the addition of promoters to the Cu/ZnO material increased the methanol/CO ratio. The space-time yield (STY) of methanol was calculated and plotted as a function of the metallic copper surface area (ACu) of the catalysts, as shown in Fig. 6 . The plot clearly shows that the increase in ACu is beneficial to the STY of methanol, which increased from 7.2 gMeOH.kgcat −1.h−1 for the CZ to 48.3 gMeOH.kgcat −1.h−1 for the CZG. A linear correlation between the STY and copper surface area was previously reported in earlier works [8,34]. The highest STY of methanol was obtained for the CZG because of its highest CO2 conversion (5.2%) and methanol selectivity (50%) at 200°C. The best catalytic performance of CZG compared to those of the other investigated materials can be correlated with the formation of smaller crystallites in this material with a higher metallic copper surface area, reinforcing the exceptional role of Ga2O3 as a structural promoter of the Cu/ZnO catalyst. These parameters are crucial to enhance the interface between Cu and ZnO and, as a consequence, to promote the superior catalytic performance of this catalyst applied to methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2 [17,31]. 4 Conclusion To systematically investigate the influence of different promoters on the performance of the Cu/ZnO catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, CuO/ZnO (CZ), CuO/ZnO/Al2O3 (CZA), CuO/ZnO/Cr2O3 (CZC), CuO/ZnO/Ga2O3 (CZG) and CuO/ZnO/ZrO2 (CZZ) were synthesized and evaluated in the methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2. Characterization results show a modification of the physicochemical characteristics of the catalysts in the presence of the promoters. Compared to the unpromoted material (CZ), smaller copper oxide crystallites and particles, higher basicity, higher specific surface areas, and metallic copper surface areas were found for the promoted materials. These characteristics are beneficial to the methanol synthesis from CO2 and H2. As a result, the promoted materials presented a better catalytic performance than the CZ. The remarkable performance of CZG, in terms of CO2 conversion and methanol selectivity, is related to the formation of the smallest particles sizes for this material with the highest metallic copper surface area among the investigated catalysts. Our findings can be extended to the synthesis of other promoted Cu/ZnO materials with specific structural characteristics to efficiently improve the production of methanol from the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. coredata.dc:description: Different promoters can be applied to increase the activity, selectivity, and stability of the Cu/ZnO for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Herein, we investigated the effect of the promoters' addition on the physicochemical properties of the Cu/ZnO-based catalysts and their performance in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. A series of Cu/ZnO catalysts, Cu/ZnO/X (X = Al2O3, Cr2O3, Ga2O3, ZrO2), were prepared by a co-precipitation method and characterized by XRF, XRD, SEM, TEM, TEM-EDS, H2-TPR, N2O passivation, and CO2-TPD. Under the explored conditions, the promoters enhanced the catalyst activity and selectivity to methanol in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The superior performance of the promoted materials was associated with the increase of specific surface area, metallic copper surface area, basicity, and the decrease of the size of copper oxide crystallites and particles. Among the investigated materials, Cu/ZnO/Ga2O3 (CZG) catalyst showed the best performance in terms of activity (XCO2, 200°C = 5.2%) and methanol selectivity (SMeOH, 200°C = 50%).
coredata.dc:title: Influence of Al, Cr, Ga, or Zr as promoters on the performance of Cu/ZnO catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol
